H0.text: Grams is the best unit of measurement for the volume of water that students collect in their beakers when they collect pond water.

H1.text: Meters are the best unit of measurement for the volume of water students collect from the pond in their beakers.

H2.text: Milliliters are the best unit of measurement for the volume of water that students collect from the pond when they collect it in their beakers.

H3.text: Centimeters are the best unit of measurement for the volume of water that students collect in their beakers when sampling pond water.

A4.text: One litre of water has a mass of almost exactly one kilogram when measured at its maximal density, which occurs at 3.984 °C.

A5.text: Cubic metres are generally used for non‑liquid commodities, such as sand and gravel, or storage space.

A6.text: The most commonly used derived unit is the millilitre, defined as one‑thousandth of a litre, and also often referred to by the SI derived unit name 'cubic centimetre'.

A7.text: The litre is defined as one cubic decimetre.
